artist: Designer: Jean Otis Reinecke; Manufacturer: Chicago Electrical Manufacturing
creditline: The Modernism Collection, gift of Norwest Bank Minnesota
medium: Chromium-plated metal, painted metal, Bakelite, electrical components
text: Initially a British invention of the early 1890s, the toaster was the first domestic appliance to make use of the new power source—electricity. The first patented pop-up toaster was designed in 1919. Named the Toastmaster, it was put into production for restaurant use by the Waters-Genter Company of Minneapolis in 1921. Chicago Electrical Manufacturing’s “Handyhot” toaster was produced in several variations, with a consistent emphasis on compact geometry
title: Handy Hot toaster, model AEUB
